summary.seg: This manuscript contains a Greek miscellany copied by Patrick Young, comprising a series of theological texts, concerning (among other matters) the seven ecumenical councils, the Orthodox faith, the cross, and, in particular, the Iconoclasm, religious movement in Byzantium during the 8th and 9th centuries that rejected the veneration of sacred icons. The volume also contains epistles by Emperor Julian, Libanius and others, and various notes by Young, in particular extracts fron Libanius' Epistles.

Patrick Young (also known as Patricius Junius, 1584-1652), was a Greek scholar, secretary and royal librarian, and published editions of Greek texts and translations from Greek to Latin. He is known for his keen interest in Greek manuscripts and for his habit of copying texts from the libraries he visited. Amasis' letters, present in this manuscript on f. 85r, were copied by Young from Oxford, Bodleian Library, Barocci 219 , as stated by him in a marginal note. Young worked with Augustine Lindsell on an inventory of the Barocci collection for the Bodleian Library. After one of the texts in this manuscript, Patriarch Gennadius II's De Christianorum recta et vera fide, Young wrote a colophon, mentioning the city of London and the date of 5 November 1622 (see Origin): since the manuscript is made all of the same type of paper, it was probably copied all around this same time.

msItem.title: Table of contents of the manuscript

msItem.author: Photius I, Patriarch of Constantinople
msItem.title: Epistula 1, excerptum (De septem Synodis Oecumenicis)
msItem.rubric: f. 1r Αἱ ἁγίαι καὶ οἰκουμενικαὶ ἕπτα συνόδοι. Φωτίου πατριάρχου Κωνσταντινουπόλεως ἐκ τῆς πρὸς Μιχαὴλ τὸν ἄρχοντα Βουλγαρίας ἐπιστολῆς, περὶ τῶν ἑπτὰ οἰκουμενικῶν συνόδων παράτιτλος
msItem.incipit: f. 1r Ἡ πρώτη καὶ οἰκουμενικὴ ἁγία σύνοδος
msItem.explicit: f. 9r καὶ ἐναγλαίζεσθαι παντὶ τῶν πιστῶν πληρώματι παρεσκεύασεν.
msItem.note: The text is an excerpt concerning the seven Ecumenical Councils, from Photius' Epistle 1 ( B. Laourdas, L.G. Westerink [eds.], Photii patriarchae Constantinopolitani Epistulae et Amphilochia (Leipzig, 1983), I, pp. 4, 63-6, 468; PG 102, 632 A11-656 A12, TLG 4040.009)

msItem.title: List of the seven ecumenical councils
msItem.incipit: f. 9v Ἰστέον ὅτι ἡ πρώτη σύνοδος γέγονε κατὰ τὸ ͵εωιϛ΄ ἔτος
msItem.explicit: f. 9v ἀπὸ δὲ Χριστοῦ ψνϛ΄.

msItem.author: Samonas
msItem.title: De Sacramento Altaris seu Disceptatio Cum Achmed
msItem.rubric: f. 10r Τοῦ μακαρίου Σαμωνα ἀρχιεπισκόπυ Γάζης διάλεξις πρὸς Ἄχμεδ τὸν Σαρακηνὸν ἀποδεικνύουσα τὸν ὑπὸ ὑπὸ τοῦ ἱερέως ἱερουργούμενον ἄρτον καὶ οἶνον, σῶμα καὶ αἶμα ἀληθὲς καὶ ὁλόκληρον εἶναι τοῦ κυρίου ἡμῶν Ἰησουῦ Χριστοῦ
msItem.incipit: f. 10r Ἐτυγχάνομεν ποτὲ πορευόμενοι τὴν εἰς Ἔμεσαν
msItem.explicit: f. 14v ἐπεὶ ὡς ὁρῶ κέκλικεν ἡ ἡμέρα.

msItem.author: Nikolaos, Bishop of Methone (active 12th century)
msItem.title: De Corpore et Sanguine Christi
msItem.rubric: f. 15r Νικόλαου τοῦ μακαριωτάτου ἐπισκόπου Μεθώνης πρὸς τοὺς διστάζοντας καὶ λέγοντας ὅτι ὁ ἱερουργούμενος ἄρτος καὶ οἶνος, οὐκ ἔστι σῶμα καὶ αἶμα τοῦ κυρίου ἡμῶν Ἰησουῦ Χριστοῦ
msItem.incipit: f. 15r Τὴν μυστικὴν ταύτην καὶ ἀναίμακτον ἱερουργίαν
msItem.explicit: f. 18r αἶμα τίμιον εἶναι τοῦ Χριστοῦ σου.

msItem.author: Nicephorus, Patriarch of Constantinople
msItem.title: Ad Leonem Armenium de sacris imaginibus
msItem.rubric: f. 19r Διάλεξις τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Νικηφόρου πατριάρχου Κωνσταντινουπόλεως πρὸς Λέοντα βασιλέα τὸν Ἀρμένιον, περὶ τῶν σεπτῶν εἰκόνων
msItem.incipit: f. 19r Βασιλεὺς μὲν ἄριστος οὗτος ἐκεῖνος ἐστίν
msItem.explicit: f. 30r καὶ πράττεται καὶ κηρύσσεται.
msItem.note:
The text, published by F. Combefis, Originum rerumque Constantinopolitanarum manipulus variis auctoribus (Parisiis, 1664), pp. 159-182, is a passage from the Life of St Nikephoros by
Ignatios, the Deacon Ignatios the Deacon , concerning his dialogue with emperor Leo 5th the Armenian (ed. C. de Boor, Nicephori archiepiscopi Constantinopolitani opuscula historica (Leipzig, 1880), pp. 139-217: pp. 170, l. 29-185, l. 18, ending in the MS on f. 27v l. 25), followed by another excerpt

msItem.author: John of Damascus
msItem.title: Expositio Fidei, excerptum De cruce (cap. 84)
msItem.rubric: f. 31r Τοῦ ἁγίου Ιωάννου τοῦ Δαμασκηνοῦ περὶ τοῦ σταυροῦ καὶ ὅτι προσκυνητέος, ἐν ᾧ καὶ περὶ πίστεως
msItem.incipit: f. 31r Ὁ λόγος ὁ τοῦ σταυροῦ, τοῖς μὲν ἀπολλυμένοις
msItem.explicit: f. 32v τῆς μερίδος τύχοιμεν Χριστοῦ τοῦ ἐσταυρωμένου. Ἀμήν.
msItem.note: The text is a chapter of John of Damascus' Expositio Fidei: P.B. Kotter, Die Schriften des Johannes von Damaskos (Berlin, 1973), 2, pp. 3-239 (pp. 186-190)

msItem.title: De confessione pretiosae crucis
msItem.rubric: f. 33r Τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Ιωάννου ἀρχιεπισκόπου Κωνσταντινουπόλεως τοῦ Χρυσοστόμου, περὶ τοῦ μὴ ἐπαισχύνεσθαι ὁμολογεῖν τὸν τίμιον σταυρὸν, καὶ ὡς δεῖ δι' αὐτοῦ ἔσωσεν ἡμᾶς ὁ Χριστὸς, καὶ δεῖ ἐν αὐτῷ καυχᾶσθαι
msItem.incipit: f. 33r Τοῦτό ἐστιν ἀδελφοὶ τὸ σημεῖον
msItem.explicit: f. 34v καὶ τῶν αἰωνίων ἀγαθων
msItem.note: The text ends incomplete at PG 52, 843 l. 1
The attribution to John Chrysostom John Chrysostom, Saint, -407 is considered spurious

msItem.title: Epistle of Olympiodoros eparchus to Nilus on the icons (reconstructed), and Nilus' answer
msItem.rubric: f. 35r Ολυμπιοδώρου τοῦ ἐπάρχου πρὸς τὸν ἱερὸν Νεῖλον ἐπιστολὴ, εἰ χρὴ ἐν τῷ ναῷ εἰκόνας ἀναθεῖναι, καὶ Νείλου πρὸς αὐτόν

list.item: f. 35r ll. 5-17 Epistle of Olympiodoros to Nilus, inc. Μέλοντί μοι κατασκευάζεσθαι σηκόν (PG 79, 577 B 13-C11)
f. 35r ll. 18-30 Epistle of Nilus to Olympiodorus, inc. Νηπιῶδες ἂν εἴη (PG 79, 577 D 1-580 A 1)

msItem.author: Leontius, Bishop of Neapolis
msItem.title: Fragmenta apologiae contra Iudaeos
msItem.rubric: f. 35v Τοῦ μακαρίου Λεοντίου ἀρχιεπισκόπου Κύπρου ἐκ τοῦ ὑπὲρ τῆς Χριστιανῶν θρησκείας πρὸς Ιουδαίους λόγου περὶ εἰκόνων
msItem.incipit: f. 35v Διὰ τοῦτο Χριστὸν καὶ τὰ Χριστοῦ πάθη
msItem.explicit: f. 36r μαρτύρων γεγόνασιν.
msItem.note: An edition of this collection of three fragments from Leontios' work: V. Déroche, 'L'Apologie contre les Juifs de Léontios de Néapolis', in: Travaux et mémoires 12 (1994), pp. 45-104 : 79-85 (reprint: G. Dagron, V.Déroche, Juifs et Chrétiens en Orient byzantin (Paris, 2010), pp. 381-451), collection Δ, the manuscript is used for the edition, and is indicated as I

msItem.author: John of Jerusalem
msItem.title: De sacris imaginibus contra Constantinum Cabalinum
msItem.note: The attribution of the text to John of Damascus John, of Damascus, Saint is considered spurious (see CPG 8114)
msItem.rubric: f. 37r Τοῦ ἁγίου Ἰωάννου τοῦ Δαμασκηνου λόγος ἀποδεικτικος περὶ τῶν ἁγίων καὶ σεπτῶν εἰκόνων, πρὸς πάντας Χριστιανοὺς, καὶ πρὸς τὸν βασιλέα Κωνσταντῖνον τὸν Καβαλῖνον, καὶ πρὸς πάντας αἱρετικούς
msItem.incipit: f. 37r Ἐπειδήπερ πολλοὶ ἐπεχείρησαν ἀνατάξασθαι διήγησιν
msItem.explicit: f. 49v νῦν καὶ ἀεὶ, εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων. Ἀμήν

msItem.title: Εἰκονομάχων προβλήματα καὶ ἀναιρέσεις τούτων
msItem.rubric: f. 50r Εικονομάχων προβλήματα καὶ ἀναιρέσεις τούτων
msItem.incipit: f. 50r Ζητοῦμεν φασὶν παρ' ὑμῶν, πῶς δυνατόν ἐστι τὸν Κύριον ἡμῶν
msItem.explicit: f. 65v οἱ τὰ πὰντα εἰδέναι οἰόμενοι, μάθετε.
msItem.note:
Some parts of the text are identifiable:
ff. 50r-59v contain excerpts from Nicephorus I Nicephorus I, Emperor of the East, -811 , Antirrhetici tres adversus Constantinum Copronymum (TLG 3086.005), PG 100, 232 A 8-252 C 4 and 309 A 4-312 D 10
ff. 61v-62r contain excerpts from Nicephorus I Nicephorus I, Emperor of the East, -811 , Pseudo-Epiphanii sive Epiphanidis confutatio (TLG 3086.009), J.B. Pitra, Sancti Nicephori Antirrheticus liber quartus (Paris, 1858), pp. 292-380 (p. 319 ll. 15-36)

msItem.author: Anastasius Antiochenus
msItem.title: Explicatio Fidei Orthodoxae
msItem.rubric: f. 66r Αναστασίου τοῦ ἁγιωτάτου πατρὸς ἡμῶν πατριάρχου Ἀντιοχείας, καὶ Κυρίλλου Ἀλεξανδρείας, ἔκθεσις σύντομος τῆς ὀρθοδόξου πίστεως
msItem.incipit: f. 66r Ποίας θρησκείας εἶ ἄνθρωπε
msItem.explicit: f. 67v διαιροῦνται δὲ κατὰ τὰς ὑποστάσεις, ἤτοι τὰ πρόσωπα.

msItem.title: Chiliostichos theologia, ll. 22-27 (Carmen)
msItem.rubric: f. 68r Εἰς τὴν θεότητα
msItem.incipit: f. 68r Θεὸς τὸ διττὸν οὐκ ἔχει τῶν πνευμάτων
msItem.explicit: f. 68r φέρει τὸ σεπτὸν τῆς ἀρίστης ἑπτάδος.
msItem.note: Only 6 lines are written, I. Vassis, Chiliostichos Theologia (Berlin-New York, 2002), pp. 74-75, ll. 22-27; on the transmission of this lines as an independent poem see Vassis (2002), pp. 57-62

msItem.author: Julian, Emperor of Rome
msItem.title: De regno, excerptum
msItem.rubric: f. 70r Iuliani Imperatoris de Regno, quae in editione Cantoclari desiderantur
msItem.incipit: f. 70r Δῆλον δὲ ἐνθένδε· ἄλλων γὰρ οὐδὲ εἰδότες
msItem.explicit: f. 78r ἀλλ’ ὥρα λοιπὸν πρὸς ἔργον τρέπεσθαι.
msItem.note: The text starts from J. Bidez, L'empereur Julien. Oeuvres complètes (Paris, 1932), 1.1, pp. 116-180: p. 157, 25 l. 49; as mentioned in the title, it is the part of the text missing in the edition of the text by Charles de Chantecler (Carolus Cantoclarus) Chantecler, Charles de, active 1577-1620 of 1583

msItem.author: Gennadius II, Patriarch of Constantinople
msItem.title: De Christianorum recta et vera fide
msItem.rubric: f. 79r Γενναδίου τοῦ σχολαρίου πατριάρχου Κωνσταντινουπόλεως ἀπολογία πρὸς τὸν ἀμηρὰν Μεχμέτην ἐρωτήσαντα περὶ τῆς τῶν Χριστιανῶν ἁγίας καὶ ἱερᾶς πίστεως
msItem.incipit: f. 79r Πιστεύομεν ὅτι ἔστι Θεός δημιουργὸς πάντων ὅσα εἰσίν
msItem.explicit: f. 82v l. 9 καὶ εἰ μὴ ἦν ἡ πίστις ἡμῶν αὕτη ἐκ θελήματος τοῦ Θεοῦ, διελύθη ἂν εὐκόλως.

msItem.author: Libanius
msItem.title: Epistula 96b (Bidez)
msItem.incipit: f. 82v l. 12 Εἰ ταῦτα γλώττης ἀργοτέρας
msItem.explicit: f. 82v l. 15 λείπεται τὸ σιγᾶν.
msItem.note: The text ends incomplete at l. 4 (ed. J. Bidez, L'empereur Julien. Oeuvres complètes, 1.2, Paris 1960, p. 177 l. 2)

In the margin the scribe indicated the nature of the text and the reference to the 1583 edition of Julian by Charles de Chantecler ( Libanii responsio ad Iuliani epistulam quae exstat pag. 154 editionis Cantoclari)

msItem.author: Julian, Emperor of Rome
msItem.title: Epistula ad Iamblichum (no. 183 Bidez-Cumont)
msItem.rubric: f. 83r Epistula Iuliani Ἰαμβλίχῳ
msItem.incipit: f. 83r Ἦλθες καὶ ἐποίησας
msItem.explicit: f. 83v l. 31 τῆς ψυχῆς ὁμογενὲς ἐμφαίνοντες.
msItem.note: The letter, attributed to Julian, Emperor of Rome, 331-363 Julian, Emperor of Rome, 331-363 , is considered spurious, see J. Bidez, L'empereur Julien. Oeuvres complètes, 1.2, Paris 1960, p. 237, no. 183

msItem.title: Epistula ad Iamblichum (no. 181 Bidez-Cumont)
msItem.rubric: f. 83v l. 32 Τῷ αὐτῷ
msItem.incipit: f. 83v Ἰκανὴν ὁμολογῶ τῆς σῆς ἀπολείψεως
msItem.explicit: f. 84v l. 4 ἢ τῆς Ἀσκληπιοῦ χειρὸς παρ' ἡμῶν κρίνεται.
msItem.note: The attribution of the letter to Julian, Emperor of Rome, 331-363 Julian, Emperor of Rome (331-363) is considered spurious: see J. Bidez, L'empereur Julien. Oeuvres complètes (Paris, 1960), 1.22 , p. 236, no. 181

msItem.author: Julian, Emperor of Rome
msItem.title: Epistula ad Eustatium
msItem.rubric: f. 84v l. 5 Λιβανίω σοφιστῇ και κοιαίστωρι
msItem.incipit: f. 84v Ὡς ὤνησέ γε τὸ σύνθημα ἡμῖν μελλῆσαν
msItem.explicit: f. 84v καὶ τοῦτο κοινώσασθαί τε καὶ ἀποσημῆναι.
msItem.note: In the manuscript the epistle is indicated as adressed to Libanius
J. Bidez, L'empereur Julien. Oeuvres complètes, 1.2, Paris 19602 , p. 63, no. 36

msItem.author: Amasis
msItem.title: Epistulae duo
msItem.note: As stated by the scribe in a marginal note on f. 85r, these two epistles have been copied from MS Oxford, Bodleian Library, Barocci 219 , f. 246r

msItem.rubric: f. 85r l. 1 Ἐπιστολαὶ Αμάσιδος βασιλέως Αἰγύπτου πρὸς Πολυκράτην ἄρχοντα Σάμου φίλον αὐτοῦ καὶ τὰ πάντα εὐτυχοῦντα, ὧν καὶ Συνέσιος ἐν ἐπιστολῇ μέμνηται
msItem.incipit: f. 85r Ἄμασις Πολυκράτει ὧδε λέγει. Ἡδὺ μὲν πυνθάνεσθαι
msItem.explicit: f. 85r l. 20 τρόπῳ τῷ ἐξ ἐμεῦ ὑποκειμένῳ ἄκεο.
msItem.note: R. Hercher, Epistolographi Graeci (Paris, 1873) (repr. Amsterdam, 1965), p. 100, no.1

msItem.rubric: f. 85r l. 21 Τοῦ αὐτοῦ πρὸς τὸν αὐτὸν, ἔτι τὰ πάντα εὐτυχοῦντα μετὰ τὴν ἐπιστολήν
msItem.incipit: f. 85r Πέμψας δὲ οἱ κήρυκα ἐν Σάμῳ
msItem.explicit: f. 85r l. 27 ξείνου ἀνδρός.
msItem.note: The second letter is not present in the printed edition

msItem.author: Libanius
msItem.title: Epistula ad Letoium
msItem.rubric: f. 85v l. 1 Λιβάνιος Λητοίῳ
msItem.incipit: f. 85v Η μὲν ἀθυμία πολλαχόθεν
msItem.explicit: f. 85v l. 10 ὦ πάντες θεοί.
msItem.note: R. Foerster, Libanii opera (Leipzig, 1921-1922), 10-11, (repr. Hildesheim, 1997), no. 1202

msItem.author: Libanius
msItem.title: Progymnasmata, excerptum
msItem.incipit: f. 85v l. 11 Ερρέτω μοι γένος προαγωγῶν
msItem.explicit: f. 85v l. 32 τάχα τῶν ἑταιρῶν ἀνελῶ τὸ πικρὸν ἐργαστήριον.
msItem.note: It is progymnasma 11, section 18, R. Foerster, Libanii opera (Leipzig, 1915), 8 (repr. Hildesheim, 1997)

msItem.author: Alexander of Aphrodisias
msItem.title: Problemata, lib. 2, prooemium, excerptum
msItem.incipit: f. 87r Τὸ Ἀσκληπιοῦ δῶρον πασῶν τῶν κατὰ τὸν βίον χρειῶν
msItem.explicit: f. 87v l. 6 καὶ πρὸς τὴν τῶν πραγμάτων εὕρεσιν.
msItem.note: The text is the beginning of the prooemium of the 2nd book, J.L. Ideler, Physici et medici Graeci minores (Berlin, 1841), 1 (repr. Amsterdam, 1963), pp. 3-80 (pp. 52-53 l. 16)

msItem.title: Anonymous prooemium
msItem.incipit: f. 87v l. 7 Οι μὲν πλεῖστοι τῶν παλαιοτέρων ἰατρῶν
msItem.explicit: f. 88r καὶ παθῶν καὶ τῶν παραπλησίων.
msItem.note: The authorship and the provenance of this text are debated (see H. Flashar, 'Beiträge zur spätantiken Hippokratesdeutung', in Hermes 90 (1962), pp. 402-418; TLG 0721.022). It was believed to be an anonymous prooemium to a commentary on Hippocrates' Aphorisms ( F.R. Dietz, Scholia in Hippocratem et Galenum (Königsberg, 1834) 2, (repr. Amsterdam, 1966), pp. 244-245; TLG 0728.001). It was also hypothesized that it is the prooemium to the spurious book 3 of Alexander of Aphrodisias' Problemata ( H. Usener, Alexandri Aphrodisiensis quae feruntur Problematorum liber III et IV (Berolini, 1859)). The text is also comprised in a philosophical compilation by Michael Psellos (J.M. Duffy, Michaelis Pselli philosophica minora (Leipzig, 1992), no. 55, ll. 1249-1288; see also pp. XXVII-XXXVIII; TLG 2702.010)

msItem.author: Eusebius of Caesarea
msItem.title: Commentaria in Psalmos, excerptum in Psalmum 86
msItem.rubric: f. 90v Ευσεβίου τοῦ Παμφίλου ἐκ τῆς ἑρμηνείας τοῦ πϛ΄ ψαλμοῦ
msItem.incipit: f. 90v Ιστέον ὅτι τὰ τῷ χρόνῳ πρῶτα λεχθέντα δεύτερα κείμενα τῇ τάξει
msItem.explicit: f. 90v εἰ καὶ προήγον τῷ χρόνῳ.
msItem.note: It is an excerpt from the Commentaries on Psalms, PG 23, 1041 ll. 13-53; TLG 2018.034

msItem.title: Various notes by Patrick Young; extracts fron Libanius' Epistles
msItem.incipit: f. 91v Ex epistolis Libanii. Theodoro. Οἱ φῶρες προσεγκαλοῦσιν
msItem.explicit: f. 92r καὶ πλεῖστον ἀπέχειν μεταβολῆς.
msItem.note: An annotation in the left margin of f. 91v has been written perpendicular to the page

support.material:
ff. [i]-[v], 1-92, [vi] Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermarks:
ff. [iv]-[v], 1-92 Pitcher with one handle, with letters N B, surmounted by clover leaves and a crescent ( ca. 65 25 ), in the gutter, no exact parallels were found in the main repertoires.
ff. [i]-[iii], [vi] Pro Patria, with a countermark in a circle, in the gutter only one half of it is visible. The watermark was used in the 18th century, see: Heawood, Pro Patria 3695-3718.

foliation.p: Modern pencil foliation, in Arabic numerals, in the upper margin right from 1 to 92; 5 endleaves at the beginning (ff. [i]-[v]) and one at the end (f. [vi]) are unnumbered; ff. [ii]-[iii] are still attached along the upper edge, they have not been cut, therefore there are no digital images of ff. [ii] verso and [iii] recto. [i]-[v] + 1-92 + [vi]

collation.p: The quires have been sewn very tightly, and there is no numbering, therefore the reconstruction of the collation is difficult, particularly for ff. [iv]-[v], 1-92, where the collation has been determined chiefly with the help of watermarks. Quire 2 is a quaternion missing the first leaf, without loss of text. F. 67 is formed by two leaves glued together.

p.list:
3 later endleaves, ff. [i]-[iii]
Quire 18-1 ff. [iv]-[v], 1-5 (the first leaf is missing, without loss of text)
Quires 2-128 ff. 6-92
1 later endleaf, f. [v]

supportDesc.condition: There are humidity stains throughout the manuscript. The text block is partially split. The upper outer part of f. [iv] has been torn away. Folios [ii]-[iii] are still attached along the upper edge, having not been cut.

layoutDesc.layout: A single column of 28-30 lines (mostly 28). On all the leaves a blank margin has been left on the left-hand side; the remaining space on the leaf is filled with writing. In order to define this margin, the leaves have been folded twice vertically. ca. 180 ca. 105

handNote.p:
ff. [v] verso-18r, 19r-30r, 31r-36r, 37r-68r, 70r-78r, 79r-85v, 87r-88r, 90v, 91v-92r Hand A: all the texts have been written by
Patrick Young (1584-1652) Young, Patrick, 1584-1652 (for the identification see M.R. James, The Western Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College Cambridge (Cambridge, 1902), vol. 3, p. 41. The script is the same as in other manuscripts written by Young (for example, London, British Library, Harley MS 7522 B ), a minuscule script, slightly slanting to the right, flowing, regular in size, characterised by contrast between thin and thick strokes and small flourishing tails at the end of some vertical and oblique strokes (see e.g. rho, csi, beta, zeta, eta). Accents are not always present, as well as breathings.
The scribe wrote also variants in the margins, see e.g. f. 45v.
The text is written in a brown ink.

f. [v] verso Hand a: another hand, probaly slightly later, added entries to the index of the manuscript written by hand A, and some marginal notes passim in the margins (see ff. 39r, 40r, 41v), in a light brown ink and in pencil.

additions.p: On the left pastedown are written, in brown ink, the old marks C.77 and no 209, the present shelfmark, O.1.36, and an older shelfmark, which has been erased, O.3.42.
On f. [iv] recto is written in brown ink the old mark C.77.
A later hand (hand a) added two entries in the index of the manuscript on f. [v] verso.

binding.p: Western modern binding. Paper cover over couched-laminate boards; parchment on spine, on which are pasted three paper labels with the shelfmark. 197 145 20
binding.condition: The cover is a little discolored and worn near the edges.

origin.p: The manuscript was copied by Patrick Young (1584-1652), in England, in the first half of the 17th century, probably around 1622, as this date appears on a colophon written by Young on f. 82v, after the text De Christianorum recta et vera fide by Patriarch Gennadius II, and the codex is made all of the same type of paper.

provenance.p: It was part of the collection of the antiquary Thomas Gale (ca. 1635-1702) Gale, Thomas, 1635?-1702 (no. 155). It appears among Thomas Gale's Greek manuscripts in E. Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ, Oxoniæ 1697, p. 188, no. 5956 (122)-5961 (127).

history.acquisition:
It was donated by Roger Gale Gale, Roger, 1672-1744
in 1738. On f. [v] recto is pasted the Trinity College bookplate. On ff. [v] recto and 92r there are stamps of Trinity College.

recordHist.source: Description (2020) draws partly on M.R. James, The Western Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College Cambridge (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1902), vol. 3, pp. 41-43.

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.

monogr.title: The western manuscripts in the library of Trinity College: a descriptive catalogue
